title: Karl #2, Living with Ambiguity, Dignity of the Individual, the Good Infection
description:
Karl continues to flesh out his philosophy.
Rejects the binary choice between a materialistic world view and a world that necessitates the supernatural.
Can live with the ambiguity of how it all began.
Religion has been useful.
Enlightenment was not a reaction against Christianity, but it came about because of Christianity.
Rational inquiry gives us a glimpse into the universe, and religion provides a moral ground.
The concept of the dignity of the individual started with Jesus.
Our cultural history is important.
Distributed cognition is culture.
Political views are conservative/classical liberal.
Guy Sengstock, "It takes all of your freedom to deeply obey something."
KW - This says something fundamental about the universe and quantum physics and God's participation in the dance. This connects to the n-body problem, for the law of gravity (whatever you claim it to be) changes in nature somehow or requires more complicated calculations the more bodies that are involved, because each exerts its own gravity (or modifies space time) or responds in its own way (to spacetime) in response to the other bodies involved.  Multiply this effect not only with gravity but with all the other constants that describe the structure of the universe and you can see that there needs to be both the ultimate in flexibility (freedom) in how those laws respond to each other and the ultimate in obedience in how the universe exhibits the characteristics of these laws.

Karl's recommendations:
Nassim Taleb - Skin in the Game
Joseph Henrich - The Secrets of Our Success
